stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the session iterating on Course 15, originally a “space arcade” but pivots to a Shy-Guy–run space-colony after concluding the arcade concept has no clear ‘placeness’.  Discussion ranges from aesthetics, structure, gameplay flow, tech limits and boss ideas, while also touching on demo-release blockers and funding.

development_findings.summary: The public RTYI demo is content-complete but cannot be released because a Parallel Launcher bug prevents the ROM from booting; Kaze is cooperating with the launcher maintainer to fix it.
development_findings.quote: The RTYI demo is finished now, but there is a bug in Parallel Launcher that makes my ROM not boot. I'm currently trying to fix it together with the person maintaining Parallel Launcher.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 undergoes a major design pivot: the ‘space arcade’ idea is dropped in favour of a Shy-Guy space-colony called “Shy Sky Station”, giving the level clearer identity and platforming opportunities.
development_findings.quote: We made the important realization that the idea we had for this level is terrible, and we're going to do something better.

development_findings.summary: Level target framerate remains 30 FPS on real N64 hardware; 60 FPS is considered unrealistic for console.
development_findings.quote: We are going to go for 30 on console. 60 on console is just unreasonable.

development_findings.summary: Gameplay structure will gate three main stars behind an initial bioluminescent space-squid boss; defeating it unlocks taxis/paths to a crop farm, water storage, and rocket interior.
Kaze plans vertical, steel-beam ring architecture, low-gravity zones, flying-taxi ‘space buses’, instant-warp black holes, and propaganda TVs showing Mario killing Shy Guys.
Form-follows-function method: build broad structure first, then detail; avoids adding decoration before layout is proven fun.
development_findings.quote: No, we're not adding detail before we don't have the basics. You have to go from the broadest thing down to the finest detail. That's a waste of time.

development_findings.summary: Technical tricks: rotating UV ‘sun-glare’ effect suggested by Biobak; consideration of Fast64 mis-rendering and object-visibility bugs.
Rejected solutions: shrinking Mario model, planetary gravity, retro minigame sub-levels, and 1-to-1 arcade machines, as they hurt platforming.

context_findings.summary: Kaze values ‘placeness’ and dislikes mechanics that feel forced or linear; wants platforming to stay central, not minigames.
context_findings.quote: That's just not the Mario 64 spirit to me.

context_findings.summary: He refuses one-on-one tech support due to time and frustration limits, preferring public help channels.
context_findings.quote: I'd rather just dip out than keep going back and forth with questions.

context_findings.summary: Excitement and gratitude after a €500 donation; donations are reinvested to pay collaborators and assets.
context_findings.quote: I do put a lot of the money I get donated back into the game. Gotta pay Biobak for his work on here.

context_findings.summary: Plans to consult a copyright lawyer and possibly monetize via physical cartridges, requiring music-rights negotiations.
context_findings.quote: I actually have crazy plans to maybe, hopefully, somehow monetize this game… That's something I definitely will talk to a copyright lawyer about.

context_findings.summary: Still employed at Gears for Breakfast, which consumes significant time; has next week off for potential bonus streams.

biobak.summary: Devised the rotating-sun UV effect that gives dynamic lighting in several levels.
biobak.quote: You see the sun there, how it moves? It's a Biobak idea, but it's so good.

biobak.summary: Ongoing paid graphics work; future funding earmarked for him.

badub.summary: Composed current level music; track available on SoundCloud; may sell rights if game is monetized.

key_stories.title: Arcade Theme Abandoned
key_stories.summary: Kaze spends hours wrestling with a ‘space arcade’ concept, finding it aesthetically incoherent and gameplay-poor, culminating in a decision to scrap it and pursue a Shy-Guy space-colony theme.
key_stories.challenge: Level lacked ‘placeness’, felt random and unfun.
key_stories.process: Reviewed arcade references, tested carpets, steel-beam rings, community feedback; brainstormed alternatives live.
key_stories.outcome: Pivot to ‘Shy Sky Station’ with clear colony setting, boss-gated progression and cohesive assets.
key_stories.key_quote: We made the important realization that the idea we had for this level is terrible, and we're going to do something better.

key_stories.title: Demo Release Blocked
key_stories.summary: Although the public demo is ready, a third-party launcher bug prevents distribution.
key_stories.challenge: ROM will not boot in Parallel Launcher.
key_stories.outcome: Demo withheld until fix; quiet release planned after.
key_stories.key_quote: The RTYI demo is finished now, but there is a bug in Parallel Launcher that makes my ROM not boot.

key_stories.title: Community Donation Boost
key_stories.summary: A viewer donates €500 during stream, prompting discussion of funding and team payment.
key_stories.challenge: Independent funding for art and music.
key_stories.outcome: Funds allocated to pay Biobak and potentially musicians; reinforces idea of monetizing release.
key_stories.key_quote: I do put a lot of the money I get donated back into the game.
